commentBody: Gothmog also being the name for the Lord of Balrogs in the First Age of Middle-earth threw me off üòÇ
Crossword's favorite cookie finally gets its own puzzle
Good one! Figured out. Better than my average Wed. Loved it. Thanks!
A Geri Allen reference! How cool is that?!

On the day of the announcement that Reese's and Oreo are going to combine for two new products: Reese's Oreo Cup and Oreo Reese's Cookie. 

Double Stuff, indeed!

Yum. DS Oreos are one of my favorites (mint being the other). 

Also, I can no longer see the name A(a)ron without thinking of that one Key and Peele sketch. Even though that doesn't fit without the Aa.

"Aren't my jokes about cookies pretty sweet?"
"Nah, they're kind of crumby."

("Please don't dessert me!")
Uncrossed squares always fill me with dread.

I was expecting something more complex when I saw the marked squares.  Instead I got dreaded crossword fill ‚ÄúOreo‚Äù to the nth degree, which is kind of funny.  Not much OPACITY in sight. My biggest hang up was trying to spell DOUBLESTUFOREOS with two Fs initially.  If I hadn‚Äôt caught on quickly, it would have become apparent when I filled in the doubled squares and saw that they spelled SSTTUUFF.  I thought the graphic Oreo depictions were a nice touch.  Despite falsely getting my expectations up, this was a cute puzzle.
What a fun Wednesday for summer! I smiled the entire way, and it may be after dark, but I wonder if the ice cream truck is going by outside?

Nice Wednesday puzzle. Had to look up the spelling of amortize, knew the answer right away. Enjoyed the new way to clue orc. Big LoTR fan here. Did a stage production of the Hobbit once. Played a troll in the first half and Smaug in the second. So I got killed twice in one show. Still one of my favorites. Caught onto the theme very quickly. Had chocolate cookie before coated. Still came in under my Wednesday average

Pretty cute, to amplify the ubiquitous cookie Into a double stuf theme. (I first thought those items were going to be dominoes.)

What might we get next?

An emu theme, filled with factoids about their egg color and running speed.

A kealoa theme, featuring as many as possible.

A ‚Äúcontested plurals‚Äù theme. You know.
S‚Äômoreo!

There is a big difference between AVERAGE and NORMAL.  The average body temperature is 98.6, but the normal body temperature can be between 96 and 99.  Average is a single number...such as the average human gestation period is 40 weeks.  The normal pregnancy can be between 38 and 42 weeks.  Sadly, AVERAGE didn't fit into the puzzle.

Inspiring story from a constructor caps off a fun puzzle.

Brain healing seems special to me, somehow.  

I don't know how many times I read 4D until I finally noticed there was only one "t" in "sigmatism"

I figured out DOUBLESTUFOREOS when all I had is SS and TT and I thought the SS answer was CLASSICROCK at the time.

I didn't even understand the STU answer until I read the column, I really thought STU was some kind of RV hookup I'd never heard of.

The last clue I got was actually EARTH cause I'm unfamiliar with the word AMORTIZES.

Really solid offering, a good puzzle all around, including of course its emphasis on one of our most winced-at pieces of crosswordese. I'm sure there will be nits.  I didn't love that stuf was spelled out in the main revealer and also constituted the bonus bit.

But this was fun.  I think I found the lower middle the most challenging to fill in.

Also, I only skimmed the article, but great congratulations on your daughter's recovery!
As a speech language pathologist and college professor for 42 years, I never once heard a lisp referred to as a SIGMATISM. Not buying it, even after I got it on the crosses.

Really enjoyed this puzzle! (Even though I am not a fan of Oreos). 

Wishing Mr. Byrne‚Äôs wife all the best!
What food could better symbolize the American diet than a Double-Stuf Oreo, Chocolate covered?  Double-Stuf, Chocolate Covered, deep fried.

"Verily, this vile victual doth offend mine very soul." 

As a act of self-discipline the ubiquitous indigestible revealer spread along the waistband of these grid was *stuffed* via down squares only.

AAARG to solve a grid teeming with spackle-filled hockey pucks.

Yes, a good puzzle. Yes, still happy to solve any puzzle, as that implies another happy day on EARTH.

But c'mon - How about SOUP? Or RICE? 
KIWI? CORN?
Or PEAS Or anything else?  

 ü§®

At first glance I knew those were OREOS!! Same old cookies, but this time they seemed intimidating.   I never had to stop writing, never had to look anything up, but I felt I was being given a real workout.  So many clues were masterpieces of OPACITY, but miraculously the crosses cleared things up every time.

Thank you Thomas and Daniel, this was a sweet debut.  You're welcome back anytime.
KEBAB, I thought.
Sam's intro to the column made me laugh!   Fun puzzle- thank you much,  Mr. Bodily and Mr. Byrne.  Also best wishes to Mr. Byrne's wife.

A similar theme published by the L.A. Times was done by David Steinberg as a Sunday puzzle ("Got Milk?") on July 8, 2012: https://crosswordcorner.blogspot.com/2012/07/sunday-july-8th-2012-david-steinberg.html
I very much enjoyed this sweet puzzle, and when it was done I loved the bonus of looking over the construction thinking, ‚Äúyou make it look easy‚Äù.  Wow!
Interesting puzzle. TIL about Double Stuf Oreos. Had no clue what they were so I initially thought I was missing something in the answer.

Cute theme. Sadly I can‚Äôt think of Oreos anymore without being reminded of the latest Selena Gomez signature Oreos. Nothing against Selena Gomez (she‚Äôs cute in ‚ÄúOnly Murders in the Building‚Äù) but still‚Ä¶no, just no. FYI if you go to the site below you have to ‚Äúaccept all cookies‚Äù, lol. https://www.oreo.com/products/selena-gomez?Size=2+Pack

Fun one, well done.

I stand by kebAb but if it makes the puzzle work then it's worth it.

STOPUP... Hmmm
I didn't know the currency of Laos and was slow to get the R-V connecter.  Everything else was well done imo.
Perfect Wednesday challenge for me and I loved the ‚ÄúIt might appear to give you options‚Äù clue. Well done Tom and Dan. I‚Äôm also glad to hear about Tom‚Äôs wife‚Äôs recovery.
The unofficial cookie of the NYT crossword becomes the official cookie of this puzzle.

I had a lot of fun with this puzzle, thanks!  One where my first pass only yielded 5 or so fills‚Ä¶ put it down for an hour, and answers gushed out.  Like I crossed into a different world sheet in a many-worlds quantum situation.  Always feels weird when things I didn‚Äôt seem to know at all flow out of seemingly nowhere.

I thought 2 Fs in STUFF.  I‚Äôve never had or bought these Oreos.

So DOUBLE STUF looks like a sort of oxymoron to me‚Ä¶ the double F has been changed to a single F!

"By serendipity, the Times puzzle became an important part of her recovery."

That's wonderful!
daaaaaaaang!  that was harder than the average wednesday!  me like!

Mr. Byrne, I am so moved by your account of your wife's struggle and resilience. May the worst of it be behind you and her full recovery now come in leaps and bounds. As for the puzzle, considering that OREO is the crossword cookie of choice, it was about time it got its very own grid! (I must, however, confess that I have never eaten one with MILK. Never have and never will. I wonder if I'm the only one on EARTH?) This was a delightful puzzle to solve. Many thanks to Mr. Byrne and Mr. Bodily! ............................................. David Byrne and Marisa Monte sing "Waters of March" - https://youtu.be/US1f_XSuRAA?si=yG9n7F2UF1dpVKx5
Nabisco unofficially owns the Crossword

œâœÅŒ±ŒØŒø 

Thanks
Much harder Wednesday than usual.  Appreciated.
This was such a fun one. Very much enjoyed.
So much for the ‚ÄúCrosswords must not have unchecked squares‚Äù rule.
I'd like it more if 6D fit the Double Stuf theme. Still a fun puzzle.

Congratulations on a fine NYT debut, Mr. Byrne!

I was sorry to read of your wife‚Äôs brain injury. But it sounds like she is recovering well. I hope that continues and that she heals fully and quickly. 

It was fun to see ORC clued in reference to Grishn√°kh. We long ago had a Doberman we named after that orc. 

Thanks, gents.
I long for the day when OREO is not in any of the crosswords I do. I think it appears in at least one per day, every day.
It would be good to have a puzzle that didn‚Äôt require detailed knowledge of varieties of Oreo.
Hats off to Messrs. Byrne and Bodily for making a puzzle with the theme of Oreos! Those guys are fearless!

Not just oreos, but theme-flaunting, grid-spanning, proudly overstuffed OREOS! I admire the all-in effort, and applaud the constructors for their bravery. Sweet puzzle, guys.

Did anyone else expect some different letters after S_ _ for ‚ÄúR-V hookup‚Äù? You know what they say, if the R-V‚Äôs a-rockin‚Äô‚Ä¶.

A fun Wednesday puzzle blissfully free of social media influencers, pop or rap singers, and with only one TV reference. As for sports clues, well, it felt like a special gift just for me‚Äîmy beloved Utes. 

Whee!

I really enjoyed the puzzle despite having been *that* kid for whom the only thing she disliked more than Oreos was the horrid white stuff you dunk them in: m‚Ä¶k (I don‚Äôt like to write out four-letter words). Kismet dictated that I went on to marry a guy who also dislikes Oreos‚Äîalthough he does pollute our refrigerator with half-gallon containers of m‚Ä¶k. All this to say that I‚Äôve never in my adult life bought the Cookies That Should Not Be and so, somehow, I thought it was Double StufT Oreo and tried to fit that extra T into 35A. ‚ÄòTwas just a momentary hiccup, though. 

Easy breezy lemon squeezy, just right for a Wednesday, with the kind of fill other Wednesdays should aspire to. 

Now back to work. Have a good day, y‚Äôall.
What'll they think of next?

First of all, Thomas; what a heartfelt account of your wife‚Äôs recovery from what must have been a terrible time for your family. Long may she enjoy the NYT Xword.

The puzzle; for reasons not worth going into, I, a person who eats no food containing sugar, had an off day yesterday where I ate my body weight in carbs, specifically sugared ones. I predictably suffered mightily throughout the night and have what can only be described as a sugar hangover this morning. Far worse than the gin induced variety. 
So, did I enjoy the grid? I did not.
That‚Äôs not to say that it wasn‚Äôt an excellent grid, with some fantastic clues/entries: stigmatise/LISP, AMORTIZES, OPACITY. Lovely.
But the theme. Apart from the fact that I have never eaten an OREO, STUFfed or not (what‚Äôs with the single F by the way?) each sugar COATED entry made me turn a slightly more  bilious shade of green. This of course is entirely my own fault. I attach no blame to the brilliant constructors. I‚Äôm going to have a lie down now.

I'm not a fan of the cookie, but the puzzle was excellent.

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Thomas.  I'm glad you were able to team up with such a talented constructor for your first outing.

I got stuck with a bad solve on the bottom left corner with SHAD instead of SHAH for 50D (Onetime Persian title) and DUH instead of HUH for 62A ("Really?"). This was a tricky but doable Wednesday grid if not for that!
I liked it.
Long may Thomas,s wife continue to improve, ‚Äî and yes, what fun to see the double stuffed OREO.
IMHO, Double Stuf Oreos have exactly twice the perfect amount of ‚Äústuf‚Äù.

Fine puzzle, thematically and visually. Solid fill too. Enjoyed this one. 

Might have been less satisfying to those unfamiliar with the "correct" spelling of the cookie variety.

Hah! 
I‚Äôve seen a bunch of fill, but
today it was creamy-ish and very sweet!

AMpER/pRO looked‚Ä¶pretty good?
Until something was holding up the music 
and amper was the only suss answer.

Two days in a row
ended with flyspecking. 

Mr. Byrne, I‚Äôm so sorry your wife has
been through so much. 
How terrifying!

I do believe that, 
mostly on a *much* less severe scale,
many of us are keeping our noodles
in shape by solving daily.

I know I am.

Happy hump day all!
Fantastic!

Other treats traditionally served with milk - for me that would be brownies, or any rich / dense chocolate cake such as devil's food cake, flourless cho1colate cake, etc. My sister-in-law makes a chocolate whiskey cake every year during the holidays. Ingredients include cocoa powder, Irish whiskey, strong coffee, and mini chocolate chips, along with butter, flour, sugar, eggs, and baking soda. Also sea salt, ground cloves and black pepper(!) Moist, dense, and delicious. And always accompanied by a glass of milk. Recipe at NYTimes Cooking https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1014419-chocolate-whiskey-cake

Excellent!
Double stuffed - is that two flavours inside? 
I've been reading up on Oreo history; I had no idea they were so popular in the US, I assumed it was a crossword thing! Not seen as a 'top tier' biscuit in the UK, introduced widely in 2008 and is only 16th in popularity, seen as too sweet. 

I got a lot from the crossers but a couple of solutions I didn't know the meaning of:
MAV
STU
I didn't realize that product placement was part of the NYT income stream. Makes sense, though. Times are tough.

Double-Stuf Oreos are my favorite! I‚Äôm glad they finally got their own puzzle.

I, too, was touched by Mr. Byrne‚Äôs tribute to his wife. Praying for a full recovery! Doing the daily crossword is a great brain workout! 

Solved my fourth Wednesday in a row with no lookups, and I‚Äôve got a five-day streak going ‚Ä¶ into Thursday. üò¨

Thomas,
That is the best testimonial for Xwords I have ever read.  Peace and here‚Äôs to your love‚Äôs continuing recovery.
Congratulations Thomas Byrne on your NYT debut and your comments, your wife must be thrilled.  And a big thanks to Daniel Bodily and the NYT team for mentoring this talent.  Well done all.

Oh, I liked this ALLOT.  Random thoughts: 
‚Ä¢	I love, in puzzles like today‚Äôs, when seeing the empty grid makes me anxious to jump in because it looks like it‚Äôs going to be fun. 
‚Ä¢	SMORE is a nice echo in a puzzle about sweet sandwiches.
‚Ä¢	Say TOOKAPIC five time real fast.
‚Ä¢	Couple of names not clued as names (AMBER, STU), and a non-name that sounds like one (HEW).
‚Ä¢	BOTTLES next to MILK.  A lovely ping, as I haven‚Äôt thought about milk bottles in a long time.
‚Ä¢	It took impressive skill, IMO, to make the leap from conception to puzzle ‚Äì bravo, guys!
‚Ä¢	Had to think a little different than usual to fill in those unchecked theme double letters, and that was very cool.
‚Ä¢	‚ÄúSchadenfreude‚Äù and OPACITY ‚Äì two gorgeous words not often heard.

Daniel, congratulations on your 15th NYT puzzle, and Thomas, on your debut.  Thank you both for a splendid outing!

Did anyone else notice the black-white-black "oreo effect" for the doubled letters in the grid? 

Some very clever cluing!

Thomas Byrne, your story had me in tears. Thank you for such a personal tale! And I'm delighted that both your wife and daughter are thriving.

When I was in grad school, I worked at a restaurant called Oscars. It was a much needed break from writing code and reading papers. One of my regular customers (apparently with  quite the sweet tooth) told me her story, which I will paraphrase.

Years before, she had experienced a terrible fall which led to a significant head injury, leaving her in a coma for several days. When she came out of the coma, the first thing she asked of her husband was to go to Oscars. When he asked why, she said the persistent thought that roused her from the coma was a strong desire for our banana cream pie. 

Of course, her husband brought her to Oscars as soon as she was well enough and they told the story for the first time. She was convinced that the existence (and deliciousness!) of our banana cream pie saved her life.

It was a story that was repeated in our little restaurant many times over the years, and they were beaming with joy when they told it to me.

Thank you for reminding me both of this story and of the power of small things to change lives.

Interesting find about OREO in puzzles: 386 appearances in Shortz era puzzles, always clued as the cookie, in a whole bunch of differently worded ways, e.g. "Snack in a stack." 

But... 106 appearances in pre-Shortz puzzles and... always clued as "Mountain; comb. form." or "Mountain: prefix." except for one time clued as "Mountainous cookie?"

Brow furrowed. 

...
Great to see an entire puzzle built thematically around our frequent guest, OREO.  Tom and Dan, do EMU next!

I hate how much Oreo comes up in these crosswords. It does not sit right me with that a corporation is constantly mentioned in a game. To build a whole theme around it‚Ä¶ are they being paid to do this?
Gimme sum.  I love this puzzle.

My daily obligatory gripe: "Oldies" is the correct term for these ungodly tunes that have been regurgitated for the past 50 years plus. "Classic hits" is a euphemism crafted to make us feel better about our inexplicable desire to cling to them--kind of like calling Twitter (or X, or whatever) "social media." Am I right, folks? Anyone with me on this? Mean Old Lady, maybe...???
What touching constructor notes! Congratulations, Thomas, on putting together a fun puzzle and getting it published!
There used to be a  Twitter account called "Is Oreo in today's crossword?", but I think it's been deleted.  Sad, because today is the day of all days for Oreos in the NYT.
Puzzle made me hhuunnggrryy!!

Fun puzzle today - thank you, Daniel and Thomas! 

Thomas, sending all good wishes to your wife in her recovery, and so nice to hear that the crossword has provided her with such engaging momentum toward her progress.

A word about the differences of opinion regarding the ubiquity of Oreos in the crossword -- can we at least agree that their plural format is correct, unlike yesterday's panini?

Most of my thoughts I put in a reply to @Lewis, but the thought of "limited edition" chocolate-coated oreos reminded me of my all-time favorite Letterykenny scene: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LNKHTNc4ibQ (Definitely NSFW language.)
Oh right, Benny the Beaver is the mascot of Oregon State University (the other, other OSU) and not Tim. MIT has a mascot? I did know their teams are called the Engineers.
Bugs always struck me as having more of Bronx accent. Oh well. Splitting hares, I suppose...

Strands #514
‚ÄúYou've got that right‚Äù
üîµüîµüü°üîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

I couldn't help but notice they done left out right to bear arms....propaganda by omission....ü§î
Oreos are gross.  Fight me...

Love it! I woke up a couple days ago craving cookies, so I bought a pack of DOUBLE STUF OREOS. (I don't do it often, as I have the tendency to eat them all at once.) Even more rare: the mint OREO blizzard at Dairy Queen. I used to eat there a lot, but after working at the local DQ for three whole days as a teenager, I became disenchanted with the place.

The constructor notes were especially heartwarming. Best of luck to Tom and his wife.
An ode to the Oreo. Bravoreo!

I've always considered Athens the quintessential OPACITY.


Wonderful puzzle.

Even more wonderful notes.

Emus ate my comment in Mike‚Äôs thread, but
my dad‚Äôs favorite joke was-


Why was the cookie so sad?

Because his mother was crumby 
and his father was a wafer so long.

Long time player/reader, first time commenter!

I gave my 2 year old a cookie the other day (chips ahoy) only to have her yell ‚ÄúNO NO- OWEEOH‚Äù so she could have an Oreo instead. Didn‚Äôt even know she knew the word Oreo. 

Great puzzle!
Just here to complain about "ARON."

Fun Puzzle!
As usual, I solved from the bottom UP, and my first entry was (AHA!) Captain NEMO!  Rats.....I moved on and (Eureka!) cute pooch ASTA!  DOUBLE rats....  Oh, well, those were easily fixed thanks to my Pilot FriXion Pen with its erasable ink!
And all went smoothly until I reached my finale at 12A and confidently entered what I thought was CLASSIC CHIPS!  Those Nestle CHIPS have been around forever!!
Which yielded SPU  for 'R-V hookup?' Uh oh.
I finally just reluctantly changed that P to a T and came to look at the Key....where I learned that my brain had 'seen' an extra C in there.
Being an "oldie" isn't a bowl of cherries...

Note to all Constructors:
I have never seen a Broadway musical (though I did view the movie version of the wonderful "Hamilton!"...which still doesn't count.)  Please stop asking what happens in which ACT.
Best regards,
 MOL
I usually do not comment but a special treat for music lovers today...I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw the clue!  Geri Allen RIP!!

Great column today and heartfelt constructor notes. All the best, Thomas Byrne, for your wife‚Äôs continued recovery. The NYT puzzle is a family affair for us too, and my son‚Äôs degree from MIT came in handy today when I filled in 14A easily. I was always amused by the nickname for their college ring - the ‚Äúbrass rat.‚Äù

Always a great feeling when I get the gold star on my first completion.  Slowly feel like I'm improving a bit.  Aron was tricky for me.  "Privy to"  had me second guessing a bit but it went through so I'm a happy camper.  Stu was a complete guess so it would have been very hard if I didnt complete lol

Had to come to the comments to shake the idea that STU must be the ~ name ~ of an RV [park] "hookup." üòÇ And to quote Judge Haller to Vincent Gambini, "What is a UTE?" https://youtu.be/ThEf_88FFs4?si=jcRNx7eQ1kFs4ep_
How many words are in today's puzzle?
Hugely dissapointing that this grand puzzle turns out to be yet another advert for Nabisco. You are aware you charge for these puzzles?

We have a long driveway, and we get a lot of packages. (Who doesn't, post-pandemic?) 

Because some delivery people (looking at you, FedEx) would sometimes leave our packages in ‚Äì ahem ‚Äì inappropriate places (halfway up the driveway in a snow pile), we have a box with snacks in the door of our garage and a note thanking drivers for making it to the top of the driveway. 

Among the cookies, Goldfish, pretzels, Ritz cheese and crackers and peanut butter sandwich crackers, it is the Oreos that always go first. The Double Stufs seem to disappear before we even put them out!

(In the hot summer days, our UPS driver prefers ice water, and if I am home, he gets two bottles. By far, our favorite, most courteous driver!)

I held off switching to Autocheck for a while and the puzzle seemed easy enough to keep holding off. I spent 46 minutes correcting first wild guesses with new ones, but it worked. It's nice to have my streak back up to three!

Must be an American thing to have milk and a cookie. I'd have a glass of milk with a sandwich for lunch. 
I'd figured out the cookies, but couldn't fit coffee or tea into those four squares...

I liked the puzzle and felt it was more like a Wednesday should be than many recent Wednesday puzzles.   I think of Wednesdays as puzzles that have more unusual or complicated themes than Mondays or Tuesdays do, but themes that don‚Äôt make the puzzles very hard and may even make the puzzle a little easier.  A sort of ‚ÄúWednesdays are for whimsy‚Äù belief.   I‚Äôm happy this one worked like that and hope the Times publishes more whimsical Wednesday‚Äôs.

It appears putting as much advertisement for Oreos as possible has become the most important rule in crossword construction, with no unchecked squares coming in a distant second.  Sorry, this one did not sit right with me at all.
Now here's a clue: [When Aron sings "Schliesset die Augen"] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krgIXBexYz4&list=OLAK5uy_lCWhm2lPpOD_C3smI8-9lPCq96NDUDrPQ&index=7
I enjoyed this one, right level of difficulty for a Wed although I have never eaten the foodstuff in question
the blatant product placement is just awful. might as well be doing a puzzle on the nabisco website. enough with OREO!!!
I'm just here to read the comments complaining about product placement. Never fails to amuse!
How much did Nabisco pay for this product placement?

A clever new twist to a classic crossword cookie.

With thanks to the trail-blazing duo who Byrne'd a new path to Bodily go where none have went before, and much appreciation for the back-story provided. A good lesson to bialy you can be.

Salud!

Glad to hear your wife is recovering, Mr. Byrne, and thanks to both constructors for a fun puzzle! Sigmatism is a new word for me, just in time to teach the physics of sound to speech, language and hearing science students!

Be sure to drink your Ovaltine! üòÇ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mF4Bg5HdbI4 I admit that when I opened the puzzle, I was deliciously anticipating some fun tricky trick but it was still a fun and (very) fast puzzle! I missed setting a new Wednesday record by just a few seconds. Definitely amusing to have a whole puzzle dedicated to such a common crossword fill word. Just had to laugh. But it couldn't not make me think of poor Ralphie and Little Orphan Annie. üòè Having never bought the things, or had them, to my recollection, I did not know there was only one ef in stuf but it didn't bother me or mess anything up because I'm never surprised by intentional misspellings of food names like that. (Uh oh, having some flashbacks to yesterday's column! Har!) -- Mr. Byrne, thank you for a fun puzzle and also for sharing about the love of your life! I'm grateful to hear she's recovering nicely and how much the puzzles are helping. All my best to you all for continued progress and much more happiness together!

Other treats traditionally served with milk? How about that classic pairing, milk and magnesia?

Double un-stuff.

Very cute, clever and enjoyable puzzle! I‚Äôm awed by people who can construct these!

Stay cool and drink lots of water!

Such a heartwarming story, Thomas, about your wife‚Äôs injury and the role of crosswords in her ongoing recovery.  Thank you for sharing that story.

‚ÄúTherapeutic exercise‚Äù ‚Äì your words ‚Äì nails it as a description of crosswords. Good puzzles, like those in the Times, keep the synapses firing while solving all kinds of riddles, while waking up memories long dormant, while injecting humor and beauty, and while bringing TILs, which in their small way, push the brain‚Äôs envelope.  All this activity is a tonic, keeping the brain humming and happy.

Crosswords as therapeutic exercise indeed! Puzzles benefit those who use it for healing, as your wife, but also for those of use looking to enrich our lives and feel as good as we can.

Very nice puzzle ... and Thomas, about 12 years ago I had a stroke, brought about by diabetes. When I got home (after a month in the hospital) I was also reduced to just doing the Monday crosswords. Luckily I was also able to keep improving, and now I too can do pretty much all 7 days, so I can definitely relate. (Wonderful organ, the brain.) So kudos to your wife, and to you.
A nitpick on the themed entries: the "cookies" have one black row, one white row, and one black row. This they depict regular sandwich cookies, not 'double stuf.'

It‚Äôs a fun, light hearted puzzle, I think! It scared me at the top but once I got the theme the filler came through! I‚Äôm sorry Dan Bodily‚Äôs wife had a traumatic brain injury but what a beautiful story of her recovery ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π with crosswords. Plus‚Äîgood column, @Sam.

About the clue to 42 across. Not to nit-pick, but I once saw a filmed interview with Mel Blank who, correcting the interviewers assumption that Bugs was from Brooklyn, stated that he gave Bugs more of a Bronx accent than a Brooklyn one.
Its been a while since I've had to do one of these tedious oh-so-cutesy gadget puzzles. Surprisingly, it somehow makes it even worse.
Delighted by this clever construction and to learn about Tim the Beaver as well as sigmatism. Thank you for an enjoyable Wednesdayüòä
Very cute one today!

Fun! My last bit to figure out: what on earth a POLUPMENU was, lol... because I thought Moneymaker's name, being a pseudonym, might be an ALT. Then suddenly the P popped into my mind!

For some reason I thought Gothmog was a Balrog, not an orc (put orc anyway bc nothing else would fit). But it's been a few decades since I read LOTR. I read it maybe 15 times when I was in 7th grade and had a crush on Aragorn.

For many years our family had a cat named Double-stuf Oreo.  You can guess her coloring.  

Alas, we got a dog a few years after we got her, and they did not get along.  The cat moved next door where a family had small children who loved her, and an older cat that didn't like the little kids.  Everyone was happy!
On biscuits (cookies to you), and milk. Here we have a variety Ginger Nuts. When I was younger they were so hard that we were required to dunk them in milk. A really great combination.

Oh, what a fun puzzle! And what a clever way to reference that oft-used bit of crosswordese! Loved the visual aid and the apt STUFfing. Mr. Byrne, I hope your wife continues to improve. It's wonderful to find out how these puzzles are helping her.

@sotto voce

I‚Äôm not a fan of sweets or processed food
in general, but an occasional Oreo, 
dunked in milk to get perfectly soft enough
to melt in one‚Äôs mouth,
is a lovely treat.

My Swedish hippie mother grew up
very money-poor, and milk was a
luxury in northern Sweden.

So they would dunk their cookies in water.

I so remember her standing at our kitchen sink,
running a lemon snap under the faucet.

My teenaged brother said,
‚ÄúOh, mom. That just bums me out.
You can afford milk now!‚Äù

Mamma just said,
‚ÄúBut then it wouldn‚Äôt taste like my childhood‚Ä¶‚Äù
